pros: Team specific, but my work is interesting and my manager supports my growth
cons:
- stupid comp structure 
- RTO 
- lots of work 
- vibes based decision making from L10+ leadership

pros: Culture is interesting you can learn from smart people around you
cons: Avoid operations it’s always a risk just avoid it by all means

summary: Good initial compensation, good and bad teams
pros: Work life balance can be good if you choose the right team. Compensation is also good for the first 4 years after joining or if you get promoted - IF the stock does well.
cons: Expect constant reorgs, unclear and uninspiring vision, and slow career progress. Also a very individualistic culture that makes it difficult to work with other teams and even your own team.

pros:
Free coffee, shuttle bus, free bananas
Help Desk department, good benefits, slacker, internal systems
cons: Micromanaging, low pay, stack ranking, pip, no career advancement, no work life balance
reasonResign: As a high performer for over 6 years I interviewed for 6 internal positions and got declined and in each case they promoted a women with half of my qualifications. There is no room for advancement or growth. I thought I would have retired at Amazon but I was wrong. I will never go back there

pros:
Company on resume
Good pay (especially for my country)
Deeper understanding of AWS and free training
cons: From what I’ve heard, my experience is very much related to my team and their alignment to Amazon’s marketplace growth here (expansion and outbound, they told me inbound isn’t getting much traction for promotions)

summary: Not sure about future career growth
pros: Compensation is above market average but not the highest. Work life balance is great.
cons: Less benefits than market. Career growth expected in this team is thin.

pros: System very complex, if you survive there, you must be much stronger in the market. But consider that with substainable growth
cons: Toxic culture, managers are jerks, teammates backstabbing. Company full of political game.

pros: Work on large scale problems. Pretty decent compensation. Depending on manager, WLB can be pretty good.
cons: Not many perks. Management seems pretty stuck in the last.

pros: Competitive salary and autonomy to take risks.  Stock equity is solid
cons: They will ride you until the wheels fall off. Mid management is incompetent.

pros: Access to scale and knowledge about different products. Internal switch is easy if current team is not good.
cons: A lot (PIP, career path and worklife balance) team and or org culture.

pros: Pay can be decent, but this just depends on when you joined/stock prices.
cons:
Pretty much everything is bad compared to other tech companies. This includes:
* Bad management
* High oncall load
* Low bar for tech stack

pros:
Writing culture 
Ownership
You build it, you operate it
Customer focus
cons:
Comp philosophy 
Flattening limits career growth 
Location restrictions are pointless

summary: Can be good but very team dependent
pros:
- Large scale engineering
- Big, impactful products
- Lots of opportunity for growth and learning
cons:
- Very dependent on the team goals and management
- Ruthless performance evaluation with a known PIP culture
- Potentially bad WLB

summary: Only good thing was comp. Extremely bloated management and toxic office politics.
pros: Comp was good. The tech stack and opportunities were decent. Good learning
cons: Extreme levels of office politics and bootlicking required for career growth.

pros: Encourages fast decisions. Leadership principles are great foundations. Doc writing is good.
cons:
The URA culture has made the company culture toxic. People are least motivated to help each other. Everyone is up there to save there ass. People will throw others under the bus at the drop of the hat.
Doc writing is good, but they over-index on polishing the doc and keep spending weeks of multiple L6s, L7s time to present a 2 pager doc to leadership.
Some managers overdo selling to leadership and partner teams and push teams to meet those timelines.

pros: Get to work on the state of the art technology
cons:
- Lower compensation
- Career Growth slow at L6+ level.

pros: Good compen sation, good wlb depending on the team .
cons: Politics, no direction in ai teams, too many people bs’ing their way around

pros: Interesting domains to internally move and work on. Good health benefits and internal resources.
cons: Some teams have bad WLB. It is difficult to grow to L6 without right support.

pros: Good brand, a lot of smart people, good comp for 2 years
cons: A lot of your comp is tied to stock, which only vest 2x/yr and doesn't get refreshed regularly.  A lot of BAD middle management.   Culture is very cold and dog eat dog.   Extremely frugal to the point of not making sense.
reasonResign: Stagnant, no pay increase or stock refresh, 5 day RTO, poor middle management

summary: Good WLB in my team but pay is so fair
pros:
- WLB in my team is good
- manager is good
- team culture is good
cons:
- pay is not satisfied
- no free food
- project is boring

summary: Great learning and super fast career growth
pros: Rewards the efforts you put in and provides opportunities for exponential growth
cons: Need to compromise on work life balance and oncall could be hectic .

pros: You get to work with some really smart and motivated people, and pay is quite nice for earlier stage engineers in this market
cons: They do not lean into the tech culture benefits and even being on a good fresh and lively team can get worse just simply because of the company culture and it's politics from higher up management, even if your direct manager and team have best intentions

pros: Lots of opportunities to explore different products or business. Work experience related to AWS is transferable.
cons: Management passed down pressure and manipulated IC with incomplete context

pros:
Wide range of businesses
International scope and opportunities for employees
cons:
Return to office policy (5 day RTO)
No career progression
Lack of innovation

pros: Comp. But given how much you work, you're not making enough
cons: They never let you forget that you're just a human battery. Easy to replace and discard

pros: Innovative and build cool things. Deeply entrenched in many businesses
cons: Employees are not priorized in decisions. Stock proportion of pay is too large

pros:
Prestige of working for AWS
Decent comp
Lots to learn and lots of opportunities across orgs 
Fast paced and not boring
cons:
Very chaotic, lots of randomization driven by “customer” demands. More time should be spent developing proper, stable processes vs being reactive to every single escalation based on customer demands. There is a balance between operational efficiency and meeting customer needs and this has not landed yet
Image a start up business, on steroids with piles of cash behind it!! 
Hugely dynamic, fast paced, sprinting and reacting all the time - it can be exhausting
And it does not need to be, a level of maturity is required from leaders on setting strategy and priorities to stabilize the business and still achieve what is needed

pros: Amazon is a good company. Lots of learning. Wlb depends on your team.
cons: Amazon  provides only one free coffee now. RTO is a headache.

pros: You get to work with some of the smartest people in the industry. Pay is good.
cons: Not worth your mental health. Toxic culture and leadership. Downward spiral.

pros:
* I have a good team
* I have a good team
* I have a good manager
cons:
* Stack racking means no safety
* Heavy adherence to mechanisms and doc culture even in the face of innovation
